messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Cedric Beust" <cbeust@g...> wrote:
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
>
> > In JUnit it would look like this
> >
> > public abstract class FooTest extends TestCase {
> > public class FooImplTest extends FooTest {
> > public class FooOtherImplTest extends FooTest {
>
> I think the original poster wanted to reuse the same test class and
pass it
> different parameters, which would alter its behavior.
>
> Hence my suggestion of the Strategy pattern.
>

Extending an abstract TestCase is reusing the same test class.
Passing an instance was your solution.

Passing an instance of the class under test to the TestCase as a
parameter introduces a dependency which prevents the TestCase from
being run in isolation. As another poster pointed out, it is also an
intention revealing test design, as it allows the developer to test
items specific to the implementation, while highlighting what is
common to the interface.
